S – Situation:Patient is a known case of hemorrhagic stroke, currently with residual neurological sequelae.Patient is in a vegetative state, GCS 5T/10, non-responsive.Tracheostomized, breathing spontaneously on T-piece, maintaining adequate oxygenation (SpO₂ 95%).Receiving PEG feeding, well tolerated.P – Problem List (Relevant to Physiotherapy):Reduced consciousness and neurological impairment (GCS 5T/10)Tracheostomy with spontaneous ventilation – airway clearance needsImmobility – high risk for contractures, pressure injuries, and deconditioningLong-term dependency for all activities of daily living (ADLs)Placement planning – candidate for Long-Term Care Facility (LTCF)A – Assessment (Physiotherapy Focus):Neurological: Patient remains in a vegetative state with no active motor response. GCS 5T/10.Respiratory: Breathing spontaneously via T-piece. SpO₂ 95%, RR 18/min, chest clear with equal air entry. No signs of respiratory distress.Mobility: Bed-bound, non-verbal, non-responsive. Requires full passive range of motion (PROM) and positioning support to prevent complications of immobility.Skin Integrity: At risk for pressure sores; currently no visible breakdown.Tolerance to Therapy: Tolerates passive mobilization and handling without distress.R – Recommendation / Plan (Physiotherapy):Continue passive physiotherapy interventions, including full body PROM exercises to all joints daily.Reposition every 2 hours to reduce risk of pressure ulcer formation.Encourage upright sitting as tolerated (with multidisciplinary approval) to improve lung expansion and reduce complications of immobility.Maintain routine chest physiotherapy as needed for secretion management.Monitor respiratory status closely during sessions.Maintain DVT prophylaxis and liaise with medical team for any changes.Continue PEG feeding and monitor for nutritional status.Recommend placement in Long-Term Care Facility (LTCF) for ongoing custodial care and supportive rehabilitation.

S – Situation:Patient with a history of hemorrhagic stroke, currently with residual neurological sequelae.Presenting with GCS 5T/10, in a vegetative state.Tracheostomized, maintained on T-piece, breathing spontaneously.B – Background:Known case of hypertension.Long-standing neurological compromise post-stroke.A – Assessment:Neurological: GCS remains 5T/10, non-responsive, vegetative state.Respiratory: Spontaneous breathing on T-piece, SpO₂ 95%, RR 18/min; chest clear with equal air entry.Hemodynamic: Vitals stable – BP 119/70 mmHg, HR 65 bpm, Afebrile.GI/Nutrition: PEG feeding ongoing and well tolerated.Renal: Adequate urine output.Skin/Wound: Requires regular care to prevent pressure ulcers.R – Recommendation / Plan:Continue long-term supportive care.Maintain close hemodynamic and respiratory monitoring.Ensure high-level nursing care and routine tracheostomy care.Provide regular skin and wound care.Continue physiotherapy (passive mobilization).Maintain DVT prophylaxis.Continue PEG feeding and nutritional support.Add patient to list for transfer to Long-Term Care Facility (LTCF) for ongoing custodial care, respiratory support, and rehabilitation as appropriate.

SummaryDiet / Feeding-NGT feeding as tolerated.Increase feeding rate on FontActiv Diabest 5mL Q4hrs target 50mL/hr over 20hrs+ Beneprotein 2scps BID + Water flush 100mL Q4hrsDVT ProphylaxisVenopress bilaterally only.- ANtibiotics:Meropenem 1 gram q8h iv for 7 days SD 27/9/2025Regular MedicationsParacetamol 1 g IV as needed for pain/fever q8hMovichol sachet once daily via NGT if no stool passed.Levetiracetam 1500 mg IV twice daily.Ipratropium 500 mcg nebulization via ETT every 6 hrs.Rosuvastatin 10 mg PO once daily.Amlodipine 5mg NGT OD (hold if SBP <130)Local MedicationsBepanthen cream – apply sufficient amount BID.Chlorhexidine mouthwash every 6 hrs.Miconazole oral gel every 6 hrs.Hyfresh eye drops – 2 drops bilaterally every 4 hrs.Fucidin cream – apply sufficient amount BID (including neck BID).Mebo cream – apply sufficient amount BID.Diabetic PlanInsulin Sliding Scale Protocol (Human Actrapid)Monitor RBS every 6 hrs.61–150 mg/dL → 0 units  151–200 mg/dL → 3 units201–250 mg/dL → 5 units 251–300 mg/dL → 8 units 301–350 mg/dL → 10 units351–400 mg/dL → 12 units400 mg/dL → Start IV insulin infusion and notify physician.Other Instructions / Nursing CareReposition patient: semi-right or semi-left only.

Note: ​female patient 41y, NPMH, polytrauma case admitted to the ICU following a fall from 2nd floor.The patient has sustained bilateral lower limb and pelvic fractures, a cervical spine fracture, a right hemothorax, and is currently experiencing sepsis, acute respiratory failure, and acute renal failure.​The patient has undergone procedures for the placement of three external fixators.​The patient has a right femoral hemodialysis (HD) catheter, a left jugular central venous catheter (CVC), an endotracheal tube (ETT), and a urinary catheter.​GCS: 2T (no cough or corneal reflex)​The patient is currently off pressors with stable blood pressure (110/70 mmHg) after a recent HD session, but was previously on a low dose of Levophed.Renal function is improving on dialysis, but lab values are still high.An HD session was performed with a fluid removal of 4 liters.​Neurological: The patient is off sedation but remains with a GCS of 3/15. There is no cough or corneal reflex. mid dilated sluggish reactive pupils​Labs​Platelets: 14.44​Hemoglobin: 8 - 9.5​Urea: 111 (down to 53)​Creatinine: 3.5 (down to 1.3)​(PCT): 5​(CRP): 64​Bilirubin: 5.6 / 4.07​pneumothorax on CXR​EEG ordered----------------------------PENDING RECOMMENDATIONS OF DR ABDULRAHMAN BOUGES
DiagnoseName: 1- Acute respiratory failure // 2- Disorders of optic nerve, not elsewhere classified
ChiefComplaintNotes: POLYTRAUMA WITH RESPIRATORY FAILURE AND RENAL FAILURE

Note: new admission ( referral case ) from al gadaany hospitalfemale patient referred by private ambulance for further assessment and management# Medical HISTORY in THE OTHER HOSPITAL• Initial GCS 7/15, disturbed consciousness.• Intubated and mechanically ventilated.• Neurosurgical consult: No significant changes on CT brain/cervical spine.• CT cervical spine: No gross fracture/dislocation; only moderate degenerative changes.• Right-sided pneumothorax (initial and mild anterior).• Surgical emphysema: Right chest wall, neck, supraclavicular region, upper back.• Contusion: Right lower lobe of lung.• Subcutaneous hematoma: Right lower chest wall.• Displaced fracture: Lateral side of right 8th rib.• Fractures: Right 6th, 7th, 8th ribs.• ICU stay: Repeated failed extubation/weaning attempts, sedation (fentanyl/deprivan).• Pelvic fractures: Right iliac bone, Right pubic bone, Sacrum (horizontal fracture S1, vertical fracture).• Spinal injuries: Bilateral avulsion fractures of transverse processes (L3, L4, L5).• Lower limb fractures: Bilateral open ankle fractures, Bilateral calcaneus fractures.• ORIF and fixation: ankles, talo-navicular, tibio-talar, fibula, metatarsals, femur.• knee: Surrounding musculature intact (knee CT), No intra-articular loose bodies (knee CT).• Bilateral cyanosis of foot fingers, vascular changes.• Multiple facial fractures: Mandible (midline), left premolar region, Maxillary sinuses, nasal bones, zygoma, hard palate.• Bilateral comminuted fractures: Nasal bones and ethmoidal sinuses.• Rhabdomyolysis: CPK > 4000.• Acute renal failure: Oliguria, metabolic acidosis, urea/creatinine derangements.• was planned for CRRT >>NOT DONE• Hypovolemic shock: Required fluid resuscitation, noradrenaline infusion, blood transfusions.• Multiple blood transfusions: PRBCs, FFPs.• CVL in situ, functioning.==========================================by initial assessment:patient appears ill, tachypneic , in panic ,with respiratory distress on o2 mask , SO2: 90% on room airexternal fixator, on the pelvis and right femurabove knee slab bilateral for ankle fracturessutured facial skinmultiple rib fractures

Note: thanks for consultation of this pt who is 40-year-old female, post-traumaticPresented with AKI, sepsis, respiratory failure → progressed to multi-organ failure. On mechanical ventilation.She has received PRBCs, FFP, and cryoprecipitate.Labs as of today :WBC: 15 ×10⁹/LHb: 8.4 g/dLPlatelets: 79 ×10⁹/LINR: 1.7aPTT : 28 secLactate: 6.1 mmol/LUrea: 95 mg/dLCreatinine: 3.5 mg/dLALT: 1028 U/LAST: 4000 U/LFindings: Persistent coagulopathy and evidence of hepatic, renal, and hematologic dysfunction consistent with multi-organ failure.Assessment:Post-traumatic sepsis with MODS (renal, hepatic, hematologic, respiratory)Ongoing coagulopathyHigh lactate with tissue hypoperfusionPlan:Continue ICU supportive care (ventilation, vasopressors, CRRT as indicated).Transfusion support:PRBCs if Hb < 7.0 (higher if unstable/bleeding).FFP if INR > 1.5 with bleeding/procedure.Cryoprecipitate if fibrinogen < 1.5 g/L.Platelets if < 10,000, or < 20,000 in sepsis/DIC, or < 50,000 if bleeding/procedure.Serial monitoring: CBC, coagulation profile, fibrinogen, renal & liver functions, lactate.Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics, adjust per cultures.Search for and control underlying source of infection or bleedingLook for any possible exposure to toxins or drugs hepatology and I. D consultation

24-year-old malePOD 3 after exploratory laparotomy + Hartmann’s procedure for perforated rectosigmoid junctionSituation:Ill-looking, vitally stableOn sips of waterComplains of persistent hiccupsDeveloped dyspnea and tachypneaBackground:Emergency surgery for perforated rectosigmoid junctionNo significant past medical historyEarly post-operative recovery phaseAssessment:Vitals:* BLOOD PRESSURE 100/70Pulse: 110 bpmO₂ saturation: 95% (room air)General:Ill-looking ,dyspnic , tachypnicAbdomen:DistendedStoma: 100 ml intestinal fluid, patentPR: patentDrains: minimal serosanguinous outputLabs:WBC 22.6 ×10⁹/L (↑) with neutrophiliaHb 12.1 g/dL (↓), Hct 36% (↓), RBC 3.79 (↓)Na 133 mmol/L (↓), K 3.72 mmol/L (normal)Urea 15.7 (normal)CRP 152.4 (↑)Platelets 189 ×10⁹/L (normal)Cultures: MRSA negative, Candida auris negativeKey Issues:Post-op POD 3 with new respiratory distress (dyspnea, tachypnea)Sepsis picture: leukocytosis, neutrophilia, very high CRPMild hyponatremiaPost-op ileus with abdominal distensionHiccups likely from diaphragmatic irritation / subphrenic collectionRecommendation / Plan:Respiratory:Chest X-rayABG for oxygenation and acid–base statusO₂ supplementation if needed to maintain SpO₂ > 94%Abdomen:Pelvi-abdominal ultrasound → assess for intra-abdominal collection, leak, abscessMonitor stoma output and drain output closelyInfection:Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics per post-op protocolICU admission for monitoring and management of post-op sepsis and new respiratory distress

S – SituationPost-operative day 3 following exploratory laparotomy and Hartmann’s procedure for perforated rectosigmoid junction.Patient looks ill but remains vitally stable.On sips of water.Complains of persistent hiccups.B – Background24 years old male patient underwent emergency abdominal exploration and Hartmann’s procedure for perforated rectosigmoid junction.No significant past medical history documented.Currently in early post-operative recovery phase.A – AssessmentVitals: Pulse 110 bpm, O₂ saturation 95% on room air.General: Ill-looking but stable.Abdomen: Distended.Stoma: 100 ml intestinal fluid, patent.PR: Patent.Drains: Minimal serosanguinous output.Labs: WBC 22.6 ×10⁹/L, CRP 152.4 (↑), Na 133 mmol/L (↓), K 3.72 mmol/L (N), Urea 15.7.R – Recommendation / PlanEncourage early ambulation, incentive spirometer use, and application of abdominal binder.Adequate analgesia for pain control.Monitor stoma function and drain output.Maintain fluid and electrolyte balance.Daily labs (CBC, electrolytes, CRP).Continue antibiotics as per protocol.

His Labs showed PH 7.0 , HCO3 4.0 , RBS 459 mg/dl . He was started on IVF & Insulin Infusion until he is out of acidosis then he was shifted to the medical ward . His Latest VBG was PH 7.47 , HCO3 29.1 , Ketone 0.2 , His HBA1C was 14 % , Lipid profile showed TC 332 , TG 309 , HDL 36 , LDL 234 . His TSH was 0.3 , FT4 0.8 , FT3 1.2 . His RFT's revealed Urea 7.3 , Creat 0.71, NA 137 , K 4/16 , ALB 3.5 , CA 8.4 , Mg 2.15 . His LFT's were Normal . His CBC showed HB 12.7 , MCV 84 , Plat 308 . He was seen by Dietition & DM educator . He was discharged on Sep 22nd 2025 on the following medications :-Lantus 14 IU SC QD / NR 7/12/7 before meals He checked his BS at home , FBS 111 -165 mg/dl , PC 134-212 Mg/dl . He is on strict diet control . compliant to his injections .Today he came as FU . He is doing well , has no complaints .PMH -> Irrelevant Allergy -> None FH -> No H/O DM . No H/O Thyroid disordersSocial History -> Married x 1 1/2 years , has no kids , non-smoker , He works as E Commerce specialistClinically -> He looks pale , BP 114/69 , P 97 , O2 SAT 97 % , WT 80 kgs , HT 173 cm . No goiter .Plan : Check Labs ( TFT's , Vitamin D , B12 , Fe , PTH , GAD 65 ABS , Fasting C-Peptide )     Increase Lantus 18 iU SC QD     Increase NR to 8-12-8 before meals    Start on Crestor 20 mg QHS    Add Neurobion 1 tab QD     SMBS at Home     RTV in 1 week .

Thamer, a 7-year-old boy, presented with a history of cough and runny nose. On examination, he was diagnosed with otitis media and tonsillitis. He was started on a 7-day course of antibiotics, along with antihistamines and anti-cough medication for 3 days. Parents were counseled on the importance of medication adherence, maintaining good hydration, and monitoring for alarm signs such as high fever not responding to medication, ear pain worsening, difficulty breathing, refusal to eat or drink, or lethargy. A follow-up visit is planned in one week to assess clinical improvement and ensure full recovery.

S – Situation:Post-cardiac arrest with sequelae of acute cerebrovascular accident (CVA).In a vegetative state, GCS 7T, tracheostomized, on mechanical ventilation, with difficult weaning.Known left ventricular (LV) thrombus and peripheral vascular disease (PVD).On antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy.History of recurrent septic episodes.B – Background:Diabetes MellitusHypertensionIschemic Heart DiseaseLV thrombusLong-standing cardiovascular and neurological comorbidities.Multiple hospitalizations for infections and stroke-related complications.A – Assessment:Neurology: GCS 7T, vegetative state, no improvement noted.Vitals: BP 110/69 mmHg, HR 75 bpm, RR 19/min.Respiratory: On mechanical ventilation via tracheostomy, SpO₂ 98%; continued dependence with poor weaning tolerance.Renal: Adequate urine output.Nutrition: NGT feeding tolerated well.Wound Care: Ongoing management of pressure sores, under surgical and wound care teams.R – Recommendation / Plan:Add patient to transfer list for Long-Term Care Facility (LTCF) – for long-term management and supportive care.Continue close hemodynamic monitoring.Maintain ventilator support, assess weaning potential periodically.Monitor electrolytes regularly, with focus on serum sodium.Ensure high-level nursing care, including tracheostomy and pressure sore management.Continue surgical and wound care team follow-up for pressure ulcers.Implement physiotherapy and mobilization measures as tolerated.Maintain DVT prophylaxis.Continue NGT feeding and nutritional support.

S – SituationPatient remains in a persistent vegetative state following post–cardiac arrest complications and an acute CVA.Tracheostomy in place, still on mechanical ventilation with difficult weaning.Known to have left ventricular thrombus and peripheral vascular disease.On dual therapy (antiplatelet + anticoagulation).Background of recurrent septic episodes.P – Problems / BackgroundChronic Conditions:Diabetes mellitusHypertensionIschemic heart diseaseLV thrombusPrior stroke with repeated infectionsCourse/Status:Multiple ICU admissions for infectious and neurological complications.Long-standing combined cardiac and neurological impairment.Fully dependent on nursing care and ventilatory support.A – Assessment (PT-Oriented)Neurology:GCS 7T/15, unresponsive, vegetative state with no signs of improvement.Respiratory:Ventilator-dependent via tracheostomy.SpO₂ 98% on current settings.Mobility/Function:Completely dependent, bedbound.No active movement; passive mobilization applied to all limbs.Regular repositioning performed for postural care and skin protection.Skin Integrity:Ongoing management of pressure ulcers with wound care team involvement.Cardiovascular:Stable during PT review: BP 110/69 mmHg, HR 75 bpm.Nutrition:NG tube feeding tolerated, no aspiration or GI issues noted.R – Recommendations / Physiotherapy PlanMaintain daily passive physiotherapy: full PROM for upper and lower limbs.Strict repositioning schedule (2-hourly) with nursing team.Monitor patient’s tolerance and adjust physiotherapy accordingly.Observe for early stiffness, spasticity, or contracture development.Continue supportive respiratory physiotherapy (secretion clearance, positioning).Collaborate with wound care/surgical teams for ongoing skin management.Maintain current ICU measures: DVT prophylaxis, nutrition, and electrolyte monitoring.Physiotherapy involvement to continue while awaiting transfer to LTCF for long-term custodial care.

Note: S - Situation54y patient who is in the ICU for ongoing neurological and hemodynamic monitoring following an acute ischemic stroke, post-cardiac arrest, and sepsis. The patient is still in a decreased level of consciousness.B - BackgroundThe patient received antibiotics for sepsis and is currently on a T-piece via tracheostomy. The patient has a history of recurrent seizures, and the anticonvulsant medications were recently modified in response to new seizure activity. The patient is on NGT feeding and is awaiting a PEG tube insertion. The patient also has excessive airway secretions that require frequent suctioning.A - AssessmentMy assessment is that the patient's neurological status remains significantly compromised, with a GCS of 5T/10. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a BP of 130/84, HR of 80, RR of 18, and Temp of 37.1. The patient has an adequate urine output. The patient's respiratory status is being managed with the tracheostomy, but the recurrent secretions are a concern.R - RecommendationI recommend we continue the current plan of care, including close neurological and hemodynamic monitoring in the ICU. We need to continue to manage the patient's airway with frequent suctioning. We should also proceed with the planned PEG tube insertion to ensure adequate long-term nutrition. The current medical management for seizures and sepsis should be continued
DiagnoseName: 1- Stroke, not specified as haemorrhage or infarction

S – SituationPost–cardiac arrest patient, currently in persistent vegetative state.Tracheostomy in place, dependent on mechanical ventilation.Receiving physiotherapy mainly for prevention of complications and passive mobilization.P – Problems / BackgroundMedical history:Diabetes mellitusHypertensionIschemic heart diseaseICU course & current condition:Cardiac arrest with poor neurological recovery.GCS 7T/10, non-responsive.Intermittent atrial fibrillation noted.Ventilator dependent (FiO₂ 40%, SpO₂ 97%).Adequate urine output.Requires full nursing support: tracheostomy care, wound care, general hygiene.Recurrent lip bleeding observed.A – Assessment (Physiotherapy Focus)Neurology: Vegetative state, no purposeful movement, no reaction to external stimuli.Respiratory: Ventilator dependent, oxygenation stable.Mobility: Bedbound, unresponsive; PROM given to all limbs, tolerated without distress.Positioning: Regular turns for pressure area protection.Skin/Wound: No current pressure injuries; dressings intact.Cardiovascular: Hemodynamically stable during physiotherapy review.R – Recommendations / Physiotherapy PlanMaintain daily physiotherapy with:Full-body PROM exercises.2-hourly repositioning with nursing team.Provide chest physiotherapy as needed for secretion clearance.Monitor closely for early signs of joint contractures, stiffness, or skin compromise.Continue DVT prophylaxis as per ICU protocol.Sustain enteral feeding and nutritional support.Liaise with MDT for:Long-Term Care Facility (LTCF) transfer planning.Ongoing tracheostomy and wound management.Reassess physiotherapy goals regularly in line with patient status.

Clinical Summary:An 89-year-old male with significant comorbidities, including DM, HTN, Alzheimer’s disease, and pressure ulcers, On examination, the tip of the inflatable penile prosthesis (IPP) was found to be extruding through the glans penis, without active bleeding or systemic signs of sepsis. The prosthesis appears to have eroded through the distal urethra.The patient is bedbound with a generally poor clinical status, and his current condition is not directly related to the prosthesis complication.Urology Assessment & Plan:No urgent surgical intervention is recommended at this stage due to:The patient’s overall frailty and poor functional statusAdjust antibiotics according to urine and wound culture resultsprosthesis removal to be considered only after improvement in general      condition

For transfer to long term care facility89-year-old male with significant comorbidities, including DM, HTN, Alzheimer’s disease, and pressure ulcers, On examination, the tip of the inflatable penile prosthesis (IPP) was found to be extruding through the glans penis, without active bleeding or systemic signs of sepsis. The prosthesis appears to have eroded through the distal urethra. The patient is bedbound with a generally poor clinical status, and his current condition is not directly related to the prosthesis complication.Urology Assessment & Plan: 1 No urgent surgical intervention is recommended at this stage due to: 3 Adjust antibiotics according to urine and wound culture results 4 prosthesis removal to be considered only after improvement in general condition The patient’s overall frailty and poor functional status

For Transfer to long term care FacilityS - Situation89-year-old male currently in the ICU under close observation and monitoring.Increasing CRP noted.Pan-cultures have been sent (results pending).Empirical antibiotics initiated.Urine analysis revealed >100 pus cells.Inflatable penile prosthesis has eroded through the distal urethra with visible tip protruding from the glans penis.No bleeding, fever, or signs of systemic infection at this time.B - BackgroundPatient has advanced chronic comorbidities:Diabetes MellitusHypertensionAlzheimer’s diseasePressure ulcersBedbound, frail condition.No change in GCS from previous ICU follow-up.A - AssessmentElevated inflammatory markers (CRP).Evidence of urinary tract infection; UA shows significant pyuria.Prosthesis erosion noted, but currently no systemic signs of sepsis.Patient is hemodynamically stable, no acute distress.Cultures are pending to guide targeted antibiotic therapy.No immediate urological intervention required at this time.R - RecommendationContinue close ICU monitoring until culture results are available.Adjust antibiotics according to urine and wound culture sensitivities.No urgent surgical/urological action required currently.Plan for safe transfer to a long-term care facility once clinically stable.Ensure wound care and pressure ulcer management are optimized prior to transfer.

OrdersPositioning: Maintain patient in right (RT) and left (LT) lateral positions only.Physiotherapy: Daily physiotherapy.NGT Feeding Plan:Increase Nepro HP feeding rate by 5 mL every 4 hours (Q4H), targeting a final rate of 50 mL/hr over 20 hours.Administer 100 mL water flush Q4H.MedicationsEbixa (Memantine) 10 mg Tablet: Administer once daily (OD) via NGT.Risperdal (Risperidone) 1 mg/1 ml Syrup: Administer 0.5 ml OD via NGT.Vortioxetine 10 mg: Administer OD via NGT.Bepanthene Cream: Apply a sufficient amount three times a day (TID).Pantoprazole 40 mg IV: Administer OD.Clexane (Enoxaparin) 40 mg Subcutaneous (SC): Administer every 24 hours (Q24H).Atrovent (Ipratropium) 500 mcg Nebulizer: Administer every 8 hours (Q8H).Pulmicort (Budesonide) 500 mcg Nebulizer: Administer every 12 hours (Q12H).Acetylcysteine 200 mg NGT: Administer Q8H.Perfelgan (Paracetamol) 1 gm IV: Administer Q8H as needed (PRN) for fever or pain.Miconaz Gel: Apply a sufficient amount Q8H.Bisoprolol 5 mg Tablet NGT: Administer OD. Hold if (BP) < 120/80 mmHg or (HR) < 70 beats per minute.Aransep (Darbepoetin Alfa) 40 mg Prefilled Syringe SC: Administer weekly.Biocal D NGT Tablet: Administer Q12H.Mebo Ointment Topical: Apply a sufficient amount twice daily (BID).Lipobase Topical: Apply a sufficient amount BID.Argiment Sachet: Administer BID.Reparil Gel: Apply a sufficient amount BID.Actrapid Insulin (SC Sliding Scale): Administer according to protocol, based on Random Blood Glucose (RBG) every 6 hours (Q6H):RBG 150-200 mg/dL: 3 unitsRBG 201-250 mg/dL: 5 unitsRBG 251-300 mg/dL: 10 unitsRBG 301-350 mg/dL: 15 unitsRBG 350-400 mg/dL: 20 unitsRBG > 400 mg/dL: Start insulin infusion as per protocol after informing the doctor.

Administer 100 mL water lush Q4H.medxEbixa (Memantine) 10 mg tab: Administer once daily (OD) via NGT.Risperdal (Risperidone) 1 mg/mL syrup: Administer 0.5 mL OD via NGT.Vortioxetine 10 mg: Administer OD via NGT.Pantoprazole 40 mg IV: Administer OD.Clexane (Enoxaparin) 40 mg SC: Administer every 24 hours (Q24H).Atrovent (Ipratropium) 500 mcg neb: Administer every 8 hours (Q8H).Pulmicort (Budesonide) 500 mcg neb: Administer every 12 hours (Q12H).Acetylcysteine 200 mg via NGT: Administer every 8 hours (Q8H).Perfalgan (Paracetamol) 1 g IV: Administer every 8 hours (Q8H) as needed (PRN) for pain or fever.Bisoprolol 5 mg via NGT: Administer OD; hold if BP < 120/80 mmHg or HR < 70 bpm.Aranesp (Darbepoetin Alfa) 40 mcg SC: Administer once weekly.Biocal D via NGT: Administer every 12 hours (Q12H).Bepanthen cream: Apply suficient amount three times daily (TID).Mebo ointment: Apply suficient amount twice daily (BID).Lipobase cream: Apply suficient amount BID.Reparil gel: Apply suficient amount BID.Miconazole oral gel: Apply suficient amount every 8 hours (Q8H).Actrapid insulin sliding scale SC: Administer based on random blood glucose (RBG) every 6 hours (Q6H):RBG 150–200 mg/dL: 3 unitsRBG 201–250 mg/dL: 5 unitsRBG 251–300 mg/dL: 10 unitsRBG 301–350 mg/dL: 15 unitsRBG 351–400 mg/dL: 20 unitsRBG > 400 mg/dL: Start insulin infusion as per protocol and inform physion

S - Situation89-year-old male currently in the ICU under close observation and monitoring.Increasing CRP noted.Pan-cultures have been sent (results pending).Empirical antibiotics initiated.Urine analysis revealed >100 pus cells.Inflatable penile prosthesis has eroded through the distal urethra with visible tip protruding from the glans penis.No bleeding, fever, or signs of systemic infection at this time.B - BackgroundPatient has advanced chronic comorbidities:Diabetes MellitusHypertensionAlzheimer’s diseasePressure ulcersBedbound, frail condition.No change in GCS from previous ICU follow-up.A - AssessmentElevated inflammatory markers (CRP).Evidence of urinary tract infection; UA shows significant pyuria.Prosthesis erosion noted, but currently no systemic signs of sepsis.Patient is hemodynamically stable, no acute distress.Cultures are pending to guide targeted antibiotic therapy.No immediate urological intervention required at this time.R - RecommendationContinue close ICU monitoring until culture results are available.Adjust antibiotics according to urine and wound culture sensitivities.No urgent surgical/urological action required currently.Plan for safe transfer to a long-term care facility once clinically stable.Ensure wound care and pressure ulcer management are optimized prior to transfer.

S - SituationThe patient is a long-term care facility (LTCF) resident recovering from a recent critical illness episode involving acute kidney injury (AKI) and sepsis. They are currently on nasogastric tube (NGT) feeding. The plan is for transfer back to an LTCF B - BackgroundThe patient has multiple advanced chronic comorbidities, including Diabetes Mellitus, Hypertension, and Alzheimer’s disease. They are also being managed for pressure ulcers. Their baseline condition is bedbound and frail.A - AssessmentNeurologicalGlasgow Coma Scale (GCS): 11/15, which is consistent with the patient's known baseline.No new neurological deficits or concerns noted.Vital SignsStable and within normal limits: BP: 130/79 mmHg, HR: 80 bpm, RR: 20/min, and Afebrile.RespiratoryOxygen saturation (SpO₂): 94% on room air.No signs of respiratory distress.RenalRenal function is improving: Latest Serum Creatinine is 1.5 mg/dL (resolving AKI).Urine output is adequate.Infectious DiseaseSepsis markers are improving.Culture results are still pending.WoundsPressure ulcers are receiving dedicated wound care management.R - RecommendationThe patient is recovering well, but remains in the ICU for close monitoring until fully stable due to the following reasons, which require a higher level of vigilance than available at a long-term care facility:Pending Culture Results: Although sepsis markers are improving, the definitive culture results are still awaited to ensure source control and guide final antibiotic duration.Need for Continued Hemodynamic and Organ Status Surveillance: Continued ICU-level monitoring is necessary for hemodynamics, urine output, and renal function (S. Creatinine) to ensure the resolution of sepsis and AKI is sustained.Maintain:High-level nursing care.Wound care management.Physiotherapy and positioning to prevent complications.Action: Once all clinical stability parameters are met (sustained stable vitals, stable renal function, and culture results are reviewed), proceed with the planned safe transfer to the long-term care facility.

S — SituationThe patient is currently in the ICU recovering from a recent critical illness (including AKI and sepsis) and is being fed via nasogastric tube (NGT). The plan is to discharge/transfer them back to their long‑term care facility once clinically stable.B — BackgroundAdvanced age (89 years), baseline frailty and bedbound status due to Alzheimer’s disease.Comorbidities: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, Hypertension, history of above‑knee amputation (left, April 2025).Chronic issues: pressure ulcers under management, infected penile prosthesis (not requiring urgent surgery), NGT feeding (PEG tube planned).Pre‑ICU issues included sepsis (likely from pressure ulcers/UTI) and AKI.A — AssessmentNeurologic / Mental Status: GCS 11–12/15, consistent with baseline, no new deficits.Vital Signs: Stable — BP ~125/70 mmHg; HR 78; RR ~19; afebrile.Respiratory / Oxygenation: SpO₂ 94–96% on room air, no distress.Renal / Sepsis Recovery: Creatinine improving (~1.4–1.5 mg/dL); urine output adequate. Inflammatory markers (e.g. CRP) decreasing (CRP ~7). Cultures pending for pathogen identification.Nutrition: Tolerating NGT feeding; PEG tube recommended for long‑term nutritional support.Wound / Pressure Ulcers: Under active management; infections under control; no urgent surgical intervention indicated.Because of the patient’s frailty, care needs, and pending results, ongoing monitoring and support beyond what a long‑term care facility alone can safely provide is required.R — Recommendations / PlanContinue critical monitoring (vitals, renal function, infection markers) until sustained stable trends are established.Maintain ICU care until microbiology results are final, renal recovery confirmed, and the risk of decompensation is low.After meeting stability criteria (stable vitals, improving labs, reviewed cultures), transfer to long-term care facility is appropriate.At the receiving facility, ensure:  • Continuation of wound care, dressing changes, infection surveillance  • Insertion of PEG tube if NGT is not sustainable long-term  • Nutritional support and monitoring  • Dementia and frailty supportive care (mobility, repositioning)  • Routine follow-up with primary care, wound care services, and urology as needed

S – SituationThe patient is currently in a long-term care facility recovering from a recent critical illness that included acute kidney injury (AKI) and sepsis. They are being fed via a nasogastric tube (NGT). The plan is to transfer them back to the long-term care facility once stable.B – BackgroundThe patient has multiple chronic health issues including Diabetes Mellitus, Hypertension, and Alzheimer’s disease. They are bedbound and frail at baseline and also require ongoing management for pressure sores.A – AssessmentNeurological:The Glasgow Coma Scale is 11/15, which aligns with the patient’s usual baseline. No new neurological changes are observed.Vital Signs:Blood pressure is 130/79 mmHg, heart rate 80 beats per minute, respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute, and the patient is afebrile—all stable and within normal ranges.Respiratory:Oxygen saturation is 94% on room air without signs of breathing difficulty.Renal:Kidney function is improving; the latest serum creatinine is 1.5 mg/dL, indicating recovery from AKI. Urine output remains adequate.Infection:Markers of sepsis are decreasing, though culture results are still pending.Wounds:Pressure ulcers are being actively managed with appropriate wound care.R – RecommendationAlthough the patient is showing signs of recovery, they remain in the ICU for close observation due to the following concerns that require a higher level of care than what a long-term care facility can provide:Pending microbiology results to confirm infection source and finalize antibiotic therapy.Ongoing need for detailed monitoring of vital signs, kidney function, and urine output to ensure full resolution of sepsis and AKI.Continued intensive nursing care, wound management, and physiotherapy to prevent complications.Plan: Once the patient demonstrates sustained clinical stability (stable vitals, improving renal function, and reviewed culture results), they can be safely transferred back to the long-term care facility.

Summary--------------Diet---------------Change feeding to Nepro LP start at 10mL advance by 10mL Q2hrs target 60mL/hr over 20hrs- Water flush 100 mL Q4H via NGT-----------------D.V.T prophylaxis--------------------ENOXAPARIN 40MG S.C OD + Venopress bilaterally----------------Regular Medication---------------------PANTOPRAZOLE 40MG IV ODParacetamol 1 gm IV PRN for pain / fever -max 4g/days -min Interval every 6hrEbixa (Memantine) 10 mg – OD via NGTRisperdal (Risperidone) 1 mg/mL syrup – 0.5 mL OD via NGTVortioxetine 10 mg – OD via NGTBisoprolol 5 mg – OD via NGT Hold if BP < 120/80 mmHg or HR < 70 bpmLactulose syrup 30 mL – Q12H via NGT-Enema – PRN Q24HAtrovent (Ipratropium) 500 mcg nebulization – Q8HPulmicort (Budesonide) 500 mcg nebulization – Q12HAcetylcysteine 200 mg via NGT – Q8HAranesp (Darbepoetin Alfa) 40 mcg SC – Once weeklyBiocal D – Q12H via NGTDesloratadine syrup 5 mg – OD orally------------------Local Medication ------------------------Chlorhexidine M.W sufficient amount / 6hrsMiconazole oral Gel sufficient amount / 6hrsHYFRESH EYR DROS / 4HRS BILAT 2DROPSBepanthen cream – TIDMebo ointment – BIDLipobase cream – BIDReparil gel – BIDBetnovate cream mixed with Lipobase – BID topical-------------------Diabetic Plan--------------------------------Insulin Sliding Scale Protocol (Human Actrapid)(RBS) Monitoring: Every 6 hours.61–150 mg/dL: 0 units     151–200 mg/dL: 3 units201–250 mg/dL: 5 units     251–300 mg/dL: 8 units301–350 mg/dL: 10 units        351–400 mg/dL: 12 units>400 mg/dL: Start IV infusion and notify physician---------------------Other Instructions----------------------------Maintain patient in right and left lateral positions onlyDaily physiotherapy

TAZOCIN 3.375 MG IV Q 6 H FOR 10 DAYS (SD 7/8/2025)allervin one tab through ngt 4 mg BIDLASIX 40mg bid ivEbixa (Memantine) 10 mg tab: Administer once daily (OD) via NGT.Risperdal (Risperidone) 1 mg/mL syrup: Administer 0.5 mL OD via NGT.Vortioxetine 10 mg: Administer OD via NGT.Pantoprazole 40 mg IV: Administer OD.Clexane (Enoxaparin) 40 mg SC: Administer every 24 hours (Q24H).Atrovent (Ipratropium) 500 mcg neb: Administer every 8 hours (Q8H).Pulmicort (Budesonide) 500 mcg neb: Administer every 12 hours (Q12H).Acetylcysteine 200 mg via NGT: Administer every 8 hours (Q8H).Perfalgan (Paracetamol) 1 g IV: Administer every 8 hours (Q8H) as needed (PRN) for pain or fever.Bisoprolol 5 mg via NGT: Administer OD; hold if BP < 120/80 mmHg or HR < 70 bpm.Aranesp (Darbepoetin Alfa) 40 mcg SC: Administer once weekly.Biocal D via NGT: Administer every 12 hours (Q12H).Bepanthen cream: Apply sufficient amount three times daily (TID).Mebo ointment: Apply sufficient amount twice daily (BID).Lipobase cream: Apply sufficient amount BID.Reparil gel: Apply sufficient amount BID.Miconazole oral gel: Apply sufficient amount every 8 hours (Q8H).Actrapid insulin sliding scale SC: Administer based on random blood glucose (RBG) every 6 hours (Q6H):RBG 150–200 mg/dL: 3 unitsRBG 201–250 mg/dL: 5 unitsRBG 251–300 mg/dL: 10 unitsRBG 301–350 mg/dL: 15 unitsRBG 351–400 mg/dL: 20 unitsRBG > 400 mg/dL: Start insulin infusion as per protocol and inform physicianLactulose syrup 30ml q12hEnema PRN q24hDESLORATADINE SYRP 5mg / DAY ORAL ODBETNOVATE CREAM MIXES WITH LIPODOSE CREAM TOPICAL SUFEECIENT CREAM BIDPositioning: Maintain patient in right (RT) and left (LT) lateral positions only.Physiotherapy: Daily physiotherapy.NGT Feeding:Increase bolus feeding rate on Nepro HP 185mL Q4hrsWater flush 100mL Q4hrs (flush 50mL before and after each feed)

The patient is currently experiencing recurrent fever attacks and is being treated for a post-amputation site infection.wound oozing . vomiting and cultures withdrawnPOST RT THIGH HEMATOMA SURGICAL EVACUATIONB - BackgroundThe patient's initial presentation was with a stroke, complicated by severe sepsis from a diabetic foot and UTI, a GI bleed, and severe anemia. The patient is now post-right above-knee amputation due to the diabetic foot infection. Following the surgery, the stump developed swelling with serous oozing and was evacuated in the OR. The patient has a history of uncontrolled hypertension, recurrent hypokalemia, and has required intermittent BiPAP for respiratory congestion. They have a known history of a right above-knee amputation, and have been on NGT feeding. The patient is currently experiencing recurrent fever attacks and is being treated for a post-amputation site infection.POST RT THIGH HEMATOMA SURGICAL EVACUATIONB - BackgroundThe patient's initial presentation was with a stroke, complicated by severe sepsis from a diabetic foot and UTI, a GI bleed, and severe anemia. The patient is now post-right above-knee amputation due to the diabetic foot infection. Following the surgery, the stump developed swelling with serous oozing and was evacuated in the OR. The patient has a history of uncontrolled hypertension, recurrent hypokalemia, and has required intermittent BiPAP for respiratory congestion. They have a known history of a right above-knee amputation, and have been on NGT feeding. The patient recently suffered from an attack of desaturation which improved with an oxygen mask.SUPERFACIAL U/S AND MRI WITH CONTRAST SHOWED RT THIGH COLLECTION >>RT THIGH HEMATOMA SURGICAL EVACUATED AT ORR - RecommendationCORTISOL LEVELI recommend we continue the current course of treatment. The Infectious Disease team has been consulted, and the patient has completed a 14-day course of Ceftazidime/Avibactam + Aztreonam. We should continue with the recommended plan, including neuro and hemodynamic monitoring in the Neuro-ICU. We should also manage the patient's ongoing phantom limb pain, continue to monitor their electrolyte levels, and manage their hypertension. We will also need to re-evaluate the antibiotic regimen based on the new elevated inflammatory markers and culturesTHE PATIENT IS FOR PEG TUBE INSERTION FOR FEEDING (PROLONGED NGT FEEDING WITH NO NEAR OLAN FOR ORAL FEEDING)

The patient is now post-right above-knee amputation due to the diabetic foot infection. Following the surgery, the stump developed swelling with serous oozing and was evacuated in the OR. The patient has a history of uncontrolled hypertension, recurrent hypokalemia, and has required intermittent BiPAP for respiratory congestion. They have a known history of a right above-knee amputation, and have been on NGT feeding. Note: S - SituationI am calling about a patient in the Neuro-ICU with a complex history of acute ischemic stroke (post-TPA), severe sepsis, and a recent right above-knee amputation. The patient is currently experiencing recurrent fever attacks and is being treated for a post-amputation site infection.POST RT THIGH HEMATOMA SURGICAL EVACUATIONB - BackgroundThe patient's initial presentation was with a stroke, complicated by severe sepsis from a diabetic foot and UTI, a GI bleed, and severe anemia. The patient is now post-right above-knee amputation due to the diabetic foot infection. Following the surgery, the stump developed swelling with serous oozing and was evacuated in the OR. The patient has a history of uncontrolled hypertension, recurrent hypokalemia, and has required intermittent BiPAP for respiratory congestion. They have a known history of a right above-knee amputation, and have been on NGT feeding. The patient recently suffered from an attack of desaturation which improved with an oxygen mask.SUPERFACIAL U/S AND MRI WITH CONTRAST SHOWED RT THIGH COLLECTION >>RT THIGH HEMATOMA SURGICAL EVACUATED AT ORR - RecommendationI recommend we continue the current course of treatment. The Infectious Disease team has been consulted, and the patient has completed a 14-day course of Ceftazidime/Avibactam + Aztreonam. We should continue with the recommended plan, including neuro and hemodynamic monitoring in the Neuro-ICU. We should also manage the patient's ongoing phantom limb pain, continue to monitor their electrolyte levels, and manage their hypertension. We will also need to re-evaluate the antibiotic regimen based on the new elevated inflammatory markers and cultures
DiagnoseName: 1- Anaemia, unspecified // 2- Stroke, not specified as haemorrhage or infarction

Note: Patient still in Neuro ICU for close neuro monitoring and hemodynamics monitoringVital data:BP 100/65 HR 87 RR 16 TEMP 37  SO2 97% ON MV ( VENT DEPENDANT )GCS 5T/10S - Situation80Y patient in the Neuro-ICU with a primary diagnosis of acute ischemic stroke. The patient's condition is complicated by recurrent sepsis, pneumonia, and respiratory failure due to aspiration.B - BackgroundThe patient had a tracheostomy on August 16, 2025, and is currently on an invasive mechanical ventilator with ongoing weaning trials. Their consciousness level is decreased with a GCS of 5T/10, and they are on NGT feeding. Their inflammatory markers were elevated but are now improving, with the most recent CRP at 20. They have bilateral infiltrates on their chest x-ray (CXR). Vital signs are currently stable, with a BP of 110/60  and HR of 78.A - AssessmentMy assessment is that the patient's neurological status remains significantly compromised due to the acute ischemic stroke, as indicated by their low GCS. Their respiratory condition, while improving, still requires mechanical support. The patient has been switched to PS 15 and PEEP 5 and is tolerating the changes so far. The inflammatory markers are trending downwards, indicating a positive response to treatment for the sepsis.R - Recommendationcontinue the current plan of care, including strict monitoring of the patient's conscious level and vital signs in the Neuro-ICU. We will continue with ongoing weaning trials from the mechanical ventilator and closely monitor the tracheostomy site for any further oozingLTC
DiagnoseName: 1- Stroke, not specified as haemorrhage or infarction

Note: S - Situation80Y patient in the Neuro-ICU with a primary diagnosis of acute ischemic stroke. The patient's condition is complicated by recurrent sepsis, pneumonia, and respiratory failure due to aspiration.B - BackgroundThe patient had a tracheostomy on August 16, 2025, and is currently on an invasive mechanical ventilator with ongoing weaning trials. Their consciousness level is decreased with a GCS of 5T/10, and they are on NGT feeding. Their inflammatory markers were elevated but are now improving, with the most recent CRP at 24. They have bilateral infiltrates on their chest x-ray (CXR). Vital signs are currently stable, with a BP of 105/55 and HR of 73.A - AssessmentMy assessment is that the patient's neurological status remains significantly compromised due to the acute ischemic stroke, as indicated by their low GCS. Their respiratory condition, while improving, still requires mechanical support. The patient has been switched to PS 15 and PEEP 5 and is tolerating the changes so far. The inflammatory markers are trending downwards, indicating a positive response to treatment for the sepsis.R - RecommendationI recommend we continue the current plan of care, including strict monitoring of the patient's conscious level and vital signs in the Neuro-ICU. We will continue with ongoing weaning trials from the mechanical ventilator and closely monitor the tracheostomy site for any further oozing
DiagnoseName: 1- Stroke, not specified as haemorrhage or infarction

PEG tube plannedCondition is further complicated by recurrent sepsis (from pneumonia and UTI), aspiration-related respiratory failure, recent seizure episodes. B – BackgroundNo Known Past medical history Vague Cardiac Hx !! Paroxysmal AF A – AssessmentSame GCS 5-6t/15 - poor neurological      prognosis.Respiratory condition is stable but ventilator-dependent, Tracheostomy SpO₂: 97% on ventilatorSepsis under control, with downward trend in inflammatory markers.Hemodynamics currently stable but borderline:BP: 105/50 HR: 77 AF RR: 16 Temp: 37.0°CMaintained U.O.PNGT feeding Tolerated R – RecommendationContinue Neuro ICU care with close neurological and hemodynamic monitoring.Maintain current ventilator settings, continue weaning trials as      tolerated.Monitor tracheostomy site for infection or bleeding.Proceed with PEG tube insertion once approved and feasible.Continue supportive care, seizure precautions, and infection surveillance.Consideration for long-term care (LTC) placement if no neurological improvement      after stabilization

Medication Orders:Levetiracetam 1.5 g IV q12hrDepakine drops 500 mg (2.5 mL) via NGT BIDAcetylsalicylic acid 100 mg via NGT q24hrClopidogrel 75 mg via NGT q24hrClexane 40 mg SC q24hrCrestor (Rosuvastatin) 10 mg via NGT q24hrAmlor (Amlodipine) 10 mg via NGT q24hr – keep MAP 75–85 mmHgPantoprazole 40 mg IV q24hrParacetamol 1 g IV q8hr PRN if pain or feverOndansetron 8 mg IV q12hr PRN if nausea or vomitingAtrovent 500 mcg nebulization q12hrPanthenol cream topical BID – sufficient amountIf Panthenol not available, use Libobase cream topical BID – sufficient amountMiconazole oral gel topical q8hrChlorhexidine mouthwash q6hrOptifresh eye drops – 2 drops each eye q6hrFarma Active spray topical BID – sufficient amountMEBO cream topical BID – sufficient amountInsulin Sliding Scale Protocol (Human Actrapid):RBS q6hrIf 61–150 mg/dL: give 0 unitsIf 151–200 mg/dL: give 3 unitsIf 201–250 mg/dL: give 5 unitsIf 251–300 mg/dL: give 8 unitsIf 301–350 mg/dL: give 10 unitsIf 351–400 mg/dL: give 12 unitsIf >400 mg/dL: start IV infusion and notify physicianNGT Feeding Plan :Fontactive Diabest – increase rate by 10 mL every 4 hrs as tolerated until goal rate of 60 mL/hr is reachedAdd Beneprotein 3 scoops BIDWater flush 100 mL q4hrSupportive Care:Physiotherapy BID

S – Situation:62-year-old male with acute ischemic stroke involving basilar/vertebral artery occlusion, infarctions in the left occipital and bilateral thalamic regions. Currently in ICU, intubated via tracheostomy, GCS 4T/10, on mechanical ventilation.B – Background:History of mild involutional changes and chronic white matter ischemia. Complicated by recurrent infections (positive cultures), hypokalemia.A – Assessment:Patient developed hypotension; noradrenaline infusion initiated at 0.06 mcg/kg/min, titrated to maintain MAP >65 mmHg.Currently hemodynamically unstable (BP 105/60, HR 72, RR 16, Temp 37.2°C, SpO2 97%).noradrenalineNGT feeding tolerated well.Upper endoscopy: no active GI bleeding.IV Pantoprazole BID ongoing.Chest and limb physiotherapy ongoing.GCS stable at 4T/10.R – Recommendation/Plan:Continue vasopressor support as needed.Monitor hemodynamics, Hb trend, and electrolytes.Continue antibiotics; full septic screen sent.Maintain ventilatory support and chest physiotherapy.Monitor for any new bleeding signs or infection focus.

S – Situation:Patient with ischemic stroke involving basilar/vertebral artery occlusion → infarcts in left occipital and bilateral thalamic regions.Currently with GCS 6T/15 (Aimless eye opening, mild flexion – intubated, tracheostomy in situ).On mechanical ventilation via tracheostomy, nasogastric tube feeding tolerated.Was in septic shock, noradrenaline stopped as BP stable.Recently developed paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (AFib) – cardiology consulted.P – Problem:Neurological: Persistently low GCS 6T/15, post-stroke status.Cardiovascular: Resolved septic shock, off vasopressors, new-onset AFib, troponin increasing – awaiting full cardiology workup.Respiratory: Stable on MV – SpO₂ 98% on FiO₂ 25%, RR 17/min.Infectious disease: Recurrent sepsis – on Meropenem + Ciprofloxacin, CRP elevated, PCT = 1.19, awaiting new culture & sensitivity.Renal/Fluid: Generalized body edema → started Furosemide 20 mg OD.Hematological: Hb 7.4 → 1 unit PRBC transfused, enoxaparin dose reduced to 60 mg BID.GI/Nutrition: NGT feeding tolerated, no bowel movement, laxative added.Skin Integrity: Grade 2 sacral bedsore – wound care ongoing.Other: Diabetic with mild involutional and chronic white matter changes.A – Assessment:Critically ill post-stroke patient with multiple co-morbidities and complications (sepsis, AFib, low GCS, respiratory dependence).Current vitals stable: BP 120/70, HR 65 bpm, Afebrile, SpO₂ 98%, RR 17/min, off vasopressors.R – Recommendation:Close Hemodynamic Monitoring – reintroduce vasopressors only if hypotension recurs.Close Respiratory Monitoring & Support – continue ventilator support, weaning if feasible.Sepsis Monitoring:Follow-up sepsis markers (CRP, PCT).Await updated culture & sensitivity results.Consider discontinuation of steroids if hemodynamics remain stable.Bloodwork Follow-up: Monitor CBC, electrolytes.Continue High-Level Nursing Care.Wound Care: Ongoing management of Grade 2 sacral sore.Cardiology Follow-up:For increasing troponin.Management of AFib and further risk stratification.Transfer Planning:Add patient to Long-Term Care Facility (LTCF) transfer list – for ongoing supportive care, rehabilitation, and nursing needs due to poor neurological recovery.

Solucortif 50 mg iv q 6 hoursNORADRENALINE infusion 0.05-0.5 mcg/kg/min , titrate according to bp to keep MAP >65 mmhgTazocin 4.5 gm iv q 6 hours for 10 days (SD 4/8)TAVANIC 500 mg iv q 24 hours for 10 days (SD 4/8)Levetiracetam: 1.5 grams intravenously (IV) every 12 hours.Ringer lactate 40 ml/hour iv infusionBetadine solution sufficient amount bid topicalDepakine (Valproic Acid) Drops: 750 mg (3.75 mL) via (NGT) twice daily (BID).Aspirin: 100 mg via NGT every 24 hours. Hold if melena or hematemesis occurs.Clopidogrel: 75 mg via NGT every 24 hours. Hold if melena or hematemesis occurs.Clexane (Enoxaparin): 40 mg subcutaneously (SC) every 24 hours. Hold in case of bleedingCrestor (Rosuvastatin): 10 mg via NGT every 24 hours.Amlor (Amlodipine): 10 mg via NGT every 24 hours keep MAP 75–85 mmHg (hold)Pantoprazole: 40 mg intravenously (IV) twice daily (BID).Paracetamol 1 gram intravenously (IV) every 8 hours as needed for fever or pain.Ondansetron: 8 mg intravenously (IV) every 12 hours as needed for nausea or vomiting.Atrovent (Ipratropium) Nebulization: 500 mcg every 12 hours.Miconazole Oral Gel: Topical application every 8 hours.Chlorhexidine Mouthwash: Every 6 hours.Optifresh Eye Drops: 2 drops in each eye every 6 hours.Topical ApplicationsPanthenol Cream: Apply sufficient amount topically twice daily (BID).If Panthenol is not available, use Libobase Cream: Apply sufficient amount topically twice daily (BID).Farma Active Spray: Apply sufficient amount topically twice daily (BID).Mebo Cream: Apply sufficient amount topically twice daily (BID).Insulin Sliding Scale Protocol (Human Actrapid)Random Blood Sugar (RBS) Monitoring: Every 6 hours.Insulin Dosing:61–150 mg/dL: 0 units151–200 mg/dL: 3 units201–250 mg/dL: 5 units251–300 mg/dL: 8 units301–350 mg/dL: 10 units351–400 mg/dL: 12 units>400 mg/dL: Start IV infusion and notify physician.Nutrition & HydrationNGT Feeding Plan: (To be resumed on July 21st).Fontactive Diabest: Increase rate by 10 mL every 4 hours as tolerated until goal rate of 60 mL/hour is reached.Add Beneprotein: 3 scoops twice daily (BID).Water Flush: 100 mL via NGT every 4 hours.Supportive CarePhysiotherapy: Twice daily (BID).Repositioning: Resume regular repositioning.Venopress: Continue as ordered.
